document_title: Systemic lupus erythematosus: Causes, symptoms, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
Lupus pain can range from mild to severe. Most patients experience a period of active disease followed by periods of almost no symptoms. This period is called remission, but this does not mean the patient is cured. sick.
Lupus is a chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of the body. Lupus often affects the skin, joints, and internal organs such as the kidneys or lungs. There are 4 forms of lupus including:
Whole body lupus (systemic lupus) accounts for about 70% of all lupus cases. In about half of these cases, a major organ or organs in the body, such as the heart, lungs, kidneys or brain, will be affected. Some dangerous complications can occur such as lupus nephritis, affecting glomerular filtration rate, and in severe cases, kidney damage may require dialysis or kidney transplant.; Cutaneous lupus (affecting only the skin) accounts for about 10% of all lupus cases. Cutaneous lupus can manifest with cutaneous erythema or discoid erythema. The rash may be raised, scaly, and usually does not itch. Skin rashes or sores often appear on the face, neck, scalp (where the skin is exposed to sunlight or fluorescent light) or the lining of the nose, mouth or vagina. Hair loss or changes in skin color are also symptoms of cutaneous lupus; Drug-induced lupus accounts for about 10% of all lupus cases and is caused by high doses of certain medications. Symptoms of drug-induced lupus are similar to systemic lupus. However, symptoms usually decrease or disappear within 6 months after stopping use of the drug.; Neonatal lupus is a rare condition in which maternal antibodies affect the fetus. At birth, the baby may have a skin rash, liver problems or low blood cell count, but these symptoms usually disappear completely after six months with no lasting effects. Although rare, there can be a life-threatening complication called congenital heart block, which is usually detected between 18 and 24 weeks of pregnancy. The condition does not go away and the affected newborn baby is the last to be affected. will need a pacemaker.
Reference: Can end-stage lupus erythematosus be cured?
